content.question: A curve in the <math alttext="x y " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane is given by parametric functions <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="the derivative of x, with respect to t, equals, 2 minus the natural log of, open parenthesis, t cubed, plus t, plus 1, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>ln</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, 4 times the arctangent of, open parenthesis, t squared, plus 2, close parenthesis, minus 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>arctan</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The coordinates of the point on the curve where <math alttext="t equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="negative 1.219, comma 4.532, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1.219</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>4.532</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the point on the curve where <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
